name: Christopher Peikert
content: Chris Peikert Chris Peikert Ph.D. (MIT), 2006 Arthur W. Burks Collegiate Professor Computer Science and Engineering, University of Michigan (Ann Arbor) Email: cpeikert [at] umich [dot] edu, Twitter: @ChrisPeikert, Bluesky: @chrispeikert.bsky.social Office: Beyster 3601 Phone: 734 . 936 . 2974 Jump to: news — teaching — talks — research. In 2006 I received my Ph.D. from the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. My advisor was the incomparable Silvio Micali. My research interests include cryptography, lattices, coding theory, algorithms, and computational complexity. A particular focus is on cryptographic schemes whose security can be based on the apparent intractability of lattice problems. Further information may be found in my research summary. Program committee member: CFAIL 2025, ASIACRYPT 2024, CFAIL 2024, FOCS 2023, EUROCRYPT 2023, CRYPTO 2021 (program co-chair), CRYPTO 2020, CRYPTO 2019, SAC 2019, TCC 2018, FOCS 2017, EUROCRYPT 2017, TCC 2015, PKC 2015, SCN 2014, CRYPTO 2014, TCC 2014, PKC 2013, CRYPTO 2012, ASIACRYPT 2011, PQC 2011, SCPQ 2011, EUROCRYPT 2011, TCC 2011, STOC 2010, PQC 2010, CRYPTO 2009, TCC 2008. News May 2025: It is a great honor and privilege to be named the Arthur W. Burks Collegiate Professor in Computer Science and Engineering. May 2025: Our Ring-LWE paper received the Test-of-Time Award at Eurocrypt 2025! Apr 2024: Very honored to be selected as an IACR Fellow. Aug 2023: Thrilled to have received the Test-of-Time Award from Crypto 2008! May 2021: Happy to have lost all adjectives, leaving just "Professor." Feb 2019: Finally! Noninteractive Zero Knowledge for all of NP from plain LWE. Nov 2017: Thank you to the TCC community for the great honor of the Test-of-Time Award! Here's our talk. Mar 2017: I've been appointed the Patrick C. Fischer Development Professor of Theoretical Computer Science. Great thanks to the Fischer family and the University for this honor! Aug 2016: Announcing the Ring-LWE Challenges: get cracking! May 2016: Announcing Λ ○ λ (pronounced "L O L"), a general-purpose library for lattice-based cryptography! Get the paper or the code. Jan 2016: My survey A Decade of Lattice Cryptography is now available. Sep 2015: After six great years at Georgia Tech, I've moved to the University of Michigan. Go Blue! Thanks to the Google Research Awards program! Thank you to the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation!
